/.a: Yes. We operate as a 24 hour hospital in Chennai with emergency services and pharmacy support.

/.q: Can I walk in without an appointment?
/.a: Yes, walk-ins are welcome. Priority is given to emergency cases.

/.q: Do you offer pediatric emergency care?
/.a: Yes, we provide safe and prompt Emergency care in Chennai for children as well.

/.q: Do you have an in-house laboratory?
/.a: Yes, our lab operates round the clock for quick testing.

/general-medicine.q: How can general medicine help with preventive care?
/general-medicine.a: General physicians provide guidance on healthy lifestyle choices, vaccinations, screenings, and risk reduction for diseases to maintain long-term health.
Yes, most general medicine clinics offer urgent care and same-day appointments for acute health concerns.

/general-medicine.q: Can general physicians coordinate specialist care?
/general-medicine.a: Yes. If you require specialized treatment, a general physician can refer you to the right specialist and coordinate your care.

/general-medicine.q: When should I see a general physician instead of a specialist?
/general-medicine.a: See a general physician for general health issues, sudden illnesses, routine check-ups, or preventive advice. They’ll refer you to a specialist if needed.

/gynecology.q: At what age should I start seeing a gynecologist?
/gynecology.a: Start at 13–15 or when sexually active for education and preventive care; annual check-ups with screenings begin by 21.

/gynecology.q: How do I prepare for my gynecology appointment?
/gynecology.a: Avoid intercourse, douching, or vaginal meds 24–48 hours prior. Bring your medication list, cycle details, and questions. Wear comfortable, easy-to-remove clothing.

/gynecology.q: Are gynecological procedures covered by insurance?
/gynecology.a: Most plans cover annual exams and Pap smears. Coverage for procedures varies—check with your provider. Our staff can help verify benefits and assist with claims.

/gynecology.q: Will I need someone to accompany me for procedures?
/gynecology.a: You can drive yourself for minor in-office procedures. For sedation or surgery, arrange a ride and someone to stay with you for 24 hours.

/gynecology.q: What should I do if I experience complications after a procedure?
/gynecology.a: Contact us immediately for heavy bleeding, severe pain, fever, foul discharge, or trouble urinating. Call 06381601020 or visit our facility for urgent care.

/gynecology.q: How long should I wait after a procedure before resuming normal activities?
/gynecology.a: Office procedures need 1–2 days; surgeries 2–6 weeks. Follow activity guidelines and attend follow-ups for safe healing.

/pediatrics.q: At what age should I bring my child for their first check-up?
/pediatrics.a: Bring your child for their first pediatric check-up within 3–5 days after birth.

/pediatrics.q: How can I tell if my child's fever requires immediate medical attention?
/pediatrics.a: Seek urgent care for infants under 3 months with fever >100.4°F, any child with fever >104°F, fever >3 days, or severe symptoms. Mild fevers in older children can be monitored at home.

/pediatrics.q: Are vaccinations really necessary and are they safe?
/pediatrics.a: Safe, essential, and life-saving, vaccines protect children from serious diseases. Skipping them increases risk for your child and the community.

/pediatrics.q: What should I bring to my child's appointment?
/pediatrics.a: Vaccination and medical records, current medications, insurance, questions, and for infants—diapers, bottles, and comfort items.

/pediatrics.q: How do you help children who are afraid of doctors?
/pediatrics.a: Use simple language, show equipment, distract with toys/videos, praise cooperation, and prepare children calmly and honestly.

/pediatrics.q: Can parents stay with their child during examinations and procedures?
/pediatrics.a: Parents can stay during most exams and procedures for comfort and support, except in rare emergencies where safety requires otherwise.

/pediatrics.q: Do you provide guidance on child nutrition and development?
/pediatrics.a: Visits cover nutrition, development, behavior, sleep, and parenting guidance—supporting overall health, not just illness.

/ent.q: When should I see an ENT specialist instead of my general doctor?
/ent.a: See an ENT specialist for persistent issues like chronic sinusitis, recurring ear infections, hoarseness, hearing loss, nasal blockage, dizziness, or neck/throat lumps.
Most ENT diagnostic tests cause little to no pain. Minor procedures are usually painless, and surgeries use anesthesia to ensure comfort.

/ent.q: How long does recovery take after ENT surgery?
/ent.a: Minor procedures take a few days, tonsillectomy 10–14 days, and sinus surgeries 1–2 weeks. Detailed post-operative instructions are provided.

/ent.q: Can children receive ENT treatment at your facility?
/ent.a: Yes, we treat ENT conditions for all ages including ear infections, tonsillitis, adenoid issues, hearing problems, and more.

/ent.q: Will my insurance cover ENT services?
/ent.a: Most insurance plans cover ENT consultations and tests. Surgery may require pre-authorization. Our billing team can help.

/ent.q: How do I prepare for an ENT appointment or procedure?
/ent.a: Bring medical history, avoid loud noise before hearing tests, and follow fasting or medication guidelines if sedation is planned.

/ent.q: What causes recurrent ear infections and can they be prevented?
/ent.a: Recurrent ear infections are often caused by Eustachian tube issues or allergies. Prevention includes allergy management and avoiding smoke.

/physiotherapy.q: What should I wear to my physiotherapy appointment?
/physiotherapy.a: Wear loose, comfortable clothes for easy movement; athletic wear is best.

/physiotherapy.q: How many physiotherapy sessions will I need?
/physiotherapy.a: Acute issues may need 4–8 sessions; chronic or post-surgical cases may require 12–20+ sessions depending on progress.
Physiotherapy is mostly pain-free. Mild soreness may occur temporarily.

/physiotherapy.q: Can physiotherapy really help chronic conditions?
/physiotherapy.a: Yes, it improves pain, mobility, strength, and daily function while reducing flare-ups.

/physiotherapy.q: Do I need a doctor's referral for physiotherapy?
/physiotherapy.a: You can usually book directly; some insurance plans may require a referral.

/physiotherapy.q: What's the difference between physiotherapy and massage?
/physiotherapy.a: Physiotherapy treats underlying issues with assessment and exercises; massage mainly reduces muscle tension.

/orthopedics.q: How do I know if I need joint replacement surgery?
/orthopedics.a: Joint replacement is recommended for severe joint pain limiting daily activities, after other treatments fail.

/orthopedics.q: What is the recovery time after orthopedic surgery?
/orthopedics.a: Arthroscopy: 2–4 weeks, joint replacement: 6–12 weeks, spinal fusion: 3–6 months.

/orthopedics.q: Are there alternatives to surgery for joint pain?
/orthopedics.a: Yes, physiotherapy, medications, injections, bracing, and lifestyle changes are usually tried first.

/orthopedics.q: Will I need to stay in the hospital after orthopedic surgery?
/orthopedics.a: Minor procedures are same-day; major ones may need 2–5 days of hospitalization.

/orthopedics.q: How long do joint replacement implants last?
/orthopedics.a: Implants typically last 15–25+ years depending on activity level and bone quality.

/orthopedics.q: Can I return to sports after orthopedic surgery?
/orthopedics.a: Low-impact sports are usually allowed; high-impact sports depend on the type of surgery and recovery.

/dermatology.q: When should I get a mole checked?
/dermatology.a: Check moles that change in size, color, shape, itch, bleed, or look unusual.
Most procedures cause minimal discomfort, with numbing applied when needed.

/dermatology.q: How soon will I see results from chemical peels?
/dermatology.a: Superficial peels show results in 3–5 days; medium peels in 1–2 weeks; deeper peels in 2–3 weeks.

/dermatology.q: Will mole or cyst removal leave a scar?
/dermatology.a: Scars are usually minimal and fade over time with proper care.

/dermatology.q: How many sessions for tattoo removal?
/dermatology.a: Typically 6–12 sessions are needed, spaced 6–8 weeks apart.

/dermatology.q: Can skin problems indicate other health issues?
/dermatology.a: Yes—skin issues can signal hormonal, autoimmune, liver, or nutritional conditions.

/dermatology.q: How should I prepare for a procedure?
/dermatology.a: Arrive with clean skin, avoid blood thinners, and disclose allergies/medications.
